author: By Christina Morales
title: Baltimore Prosecutors Drop Effort to Cancel Adnan Syed’s Conviction

author: By Annie Karni
title: Johnson’s Budget Win Reflects a Speaker Dependent on Trump to Govern
description: The Louisiana Republican has made himself subservient to President Trump, whose help he needs to manage his fractious, unpredictable and tiny majority.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson’s success at squeezing a Republican budget resolution through the House this week, after his brush with defeat just minutes beforehand, underscored his shaky hold on his unruly majority — and how heavily reliant he is on President Trump to keep his members in line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: 16 Are Hospitalized After Smoke Fills an Upper Manhattan Subway Station
description: Investigators believe the smoke was caused by a moving train striking an object on the tracks, officials said.
content: Sixteen people were hospitalized on Tuesday after a subway train hit an object on the tracks at an Upper Manhattan station, causing a fire that filled the station with smoke, according to fire and transit officials.

author: By Danielle Pergament and Nick Ballón
title: Tuscany With a Side of Magic: Savoring Bolivia’s Wine Country

title: How ‘Right-Wing Women’ Found Their Place in the Manosphere
description: In a newly reissued 1983 book, the radical feminist Andrea Dworkin argued that conservative women understood the reality of male domination.
content: A tech mogul extols the virtues of “masculine energy”; a United States senator writes a book called “Manhood”; a president found liable for sexual abuse chooses a defense secretary accused of sexual assault (an allegation he has denied). title: An Early Bob Dylan Recording Hits the Auction Block
description: The reel-to-reel tape is from a Gaslight Cafe show in Greenwich Village in 1961, when Dylan was playing to audiences you could count in a glance or two.
content: On Sept. 6, 1961, a little-known 20-year-old calling himself Bob Dylan took the stage at the Gaslight Cafe in Greenwich Village and played a six-song set. More than 60 years later, a reel-to-reel tape of those songs has gone up for auction.
source.name: The New York Times

content: An Australian couple’s dream trip to Venice turned into a nightmare when flight attendants asked them to stay seated next to the body of a passenger who had died midflight for the final four hours of a 14-hour trip from Melbourne, Australia, to Doha, Qatar.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Israel Strikes Syria Hours After Country’s Leader Demands Withdrawal

content: The love child of Elizabeth Gilbert’s “Eat Pray Love” and Carrie Bradshaw’s “Sex and the City” column, Ada Calhoun’s debut novel, “Crush,” tells the promising story of an unnamed Gen X woman whose husband, Paul, suggests she kiss a few other men to regain her “sparkle.” Slay, droned my rotted Gen Z brain on reading this.

Her psychiatrist seems to be trying various medications, some of which require careful monitoring and are risky for women of childbearing age. My grandchild is not responsible about taking meds properly, getting lab work done or using birth control. I know her doctor can’t discuss her case with me, but would it be wrong for me to voice my concerns, given the potential risks? — Name Withheld

content: Movies contain a multitude of bodies in different sizes, colors and muscle tones, bodies that are trim, bulky, parched, surgically altered. Talking about them, though, especially women’s bodies, can be understandably fraught. For some observers, writing about them is unnecessary and objectifying, even if a lot of other people — politicians, activists, influencers, Supreme Court justices — can’t stop talking about them. “We’re always talking about the feminine condition and the role of women,” the filmmaker Agnès Varda once said. “But I want to talk about the woman’s body, about our bodies.” I want to talk about them, too.

author: By Katherine Bernard
title: How to Find Your Signature Scent
description: Take T’s quiz to figure out your perfume personality, with tips and fragrance recommendations from the experts.
content: The way you smell can say a lot about you, boldly announcing your presence or leaving a subtle lingering impression. When choosing a perfume, stay open-minded: You may love tried-and-true scents like vanilla and rose, but you might also find that unexpected notes like saffron or hay remind you of a specific memory, or help bring out a new side of your personality. Asia Grant, 30, a co-founder of the independent fragrance brand Redoux and the host of the Scent Social Club, which offers tours of specialty perfumers in New York City, recommends looking for scents that evoke your favorite emotions and sensations, such as strength or warmth. For an alternative approach, Arabelle Sicardi, 32, a beauty writer and the founder of the event series Perfumed Pages, suggests first identifying the one or two notes you love most and sampling a range of fragrances that feature them. “If you use those notes as your unifying factor,” she says, “you’ll feel more empowered to seek scents that incorporate them in entirely different ways.”

title: Wednesday Briefing
description: A minerals deal between the U.S. and Ukraine.
content: Ukraine has agreed to turn over the revenue from some of its mineral resources to the U.S., an American and a Ukrainian official said yesterday, in a deal that followed an intense pressure campaign from President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and John Bartlett
title: Chile Declares Curfew as Power Outage Sweeps Country
description: Most residents had power restored by midnight but the situation remained unstable. President Gabriel Boric blamed power companies for not acting faster.
content: Chile’s government imposed a curfew on Tuesday and sent the army and national police officers to patrol the streets in response to a sweeping blackout that cut electricity to most of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Rare Protest at U.S. Embassy in Ukraine Reflects Fears Over Trump
description: The demonstration drew only a handful of people, but showed how some Ukrainians fear that Washington is drifting away from backing Ukraine now that President Trump is in power.
content: Maryna Tymchenko walked to the U.S. Embassy on Wednesday morning and held up a homemade cardboard sign over her head: “Reagan would have hated it,” the sign read, alluding to the former president who famously called the Soviet Union “an evil empire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: One Nation, Under God
description: Americans have stopped leaving Christianity. And the country is overwhelmingly spiritual, a new report found.
content: As religion in America declined, experts administered last rites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quoctrung Bui
title: Americans Are Following the Trump News More Than I Expected
description: Despite Trump flooding the zone, Americans have not lost the plot. A majority said they were familiar with a lot of Trump news, per a new poll.
content: In little over a month, President Trump has signed over 70 executive orders and has done more than 150 things worthy of an entry in the Times Trump tracker. Some days it feels as though there is too much news to monitor — even for reporters, let alone the average reader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Nicholas Fandos
title: Cuomo Allies Form a Super PAC to Push His Anticipated Bid for Mayor
description: The super PAC, called Fix the City, was registered on Wednesday, just days ahead of Andrew M. Cuomo’s expected entry into the New York City mayoral race.
content: Allies of former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo launched a super PAC on Wednesday to boost his likely campaign for mayor of New York City, the most concrete sign yet that he is preparing to jump into the race in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sinna Nasseri and Kyle Buchanan
title: Ready for Their Close-Ups at the Oscar Nominees Dinner
description: Over 100 awards hopefuls gathered at the Academy Museum for a class photo just days before the ceremony. Our photographer and columnist were there.
content: On Tuesday night, over 100 Oscar nominees gathered at the Academy Museum in Los Angeles for a class photo in the David Geffen Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Agriculture Department Looks to Import Eggs as Prices Soar
description: The United States is in talks with several countries in an effort to immediately secure new supplies.
content: As the price of eggs reaches record highs, the federal government is looking into importing more eggs from other countries and increasing funding for efforts to combat the spread of avian flu, the Agriculture Department said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: How Trump and Biden’s Focus on Minerals Became Core to U.S. Foreign Policy
description: China dominates in critical minerals, and President Trump has turned to high-pressure tactics to acquire them.
content: President Trump’s intense interest in Ukraine’s minerals seemed to come from out of the blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Trump Says Ukraine Should Look to Europe for Any Security Guarantees
description: President Trump said Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, would visit Washington on Friday as part of a deal for Ukrainian mineral wealth. His position could ultimately embolden Russia.
content: President Trump told his cabinet on Wednesday that President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was expected to come to Washington to sign a framework agreement enabling the United States to share in the country’s mineral wealth, but he insisted the United States would not be providing security guarantees to Ukraine in return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP to Focus More on Oil and Gas in Strategy ‘Reset’
description: The energy giant said it would cut planned investment in clean energy and redirect spending toward fossil fuels.
content: BP, the energy giant, said on Wednesday that it would increase spending on oil and gas while sharply paring back investments on various forms of clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Teddy Rosenbluth and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Unvaccinated Child Dies of Measles in Texas Outbreak
description: At least 124 cases have been reported since late January, mostly among children and teenagers who were unvaccinated or whose vaccination status was unknown.
content: A child has died of measles in West Texas, the first known death in an outbreak that is spreading in the region and in neighboring New Mexico, state health officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Where Does Gucci Go Now?
description: It’s time for the brand to take some risks.
content: Ancora red is out; emerald green is in. Or so it seemed during the Gucci show at the opening of Milan Fashion Week, where it was as if Sabato De Sarno, the designer who abruptly left his job earlier this month, had practically never even been there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Karen Huger, ‘Real Housewives’ Star, Gets 2-Year Sentence for D.U.I.
description: Ms. Huger, a fixture on the Potomac franchise for nine years, will most likely serve one year of the prison sentence.
content: Karen Huger, an original cast member of “The Real Housewives of Potomac,” was sentenced to two years in prison on Wednesday for driving under the influence of alcohol and other driving violations, capping a twisting tale that put her sobriety and recovery at the center of the reality television show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Musk’s Cabinet Cameo: The Elephant in the Room Wore Black
description: At the first cabinet meeting of his second term, President Trump asked Elon Musk to speak first. The man tasked with slashing the federal government spoke far more than anyone else, other than Mr. Trump.
content: About 12 minutes into the first meeting of his new cabinet, President Trump addressed the elephant in the room. This was rather easy for him to do, since the elephant was standing 10 feet away, dressed all in black, hovering over the head of the table at which the president and the members of his cabinet sat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Influencers Call These Medical Tests Lifesaving. Here’s What You May Not Know.
description: New research examined nearly 1,000 posts on tests for fertility, testosterone levels and cancer risk.
content: The post looked simple enough: Kim Kardashian, hair pulled back in a ponytail, posed in front of an M.R.I. wearing scrubs branded with the logo of the medical imaging company Prenuvo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Intuitive Machines’ Athena Lander Launches on Journey to the Moon
description: The company reached the lunar surface in 2024, and now its second lander aims to improve on the feat. Three other spacecraft also hitched a ride on the SpaceX rocket.
content: Intuitive Machines landed a robot on the moon last year. Can the Houston company do it again, but keep the spacecraft upright this time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Goals
description: What goals have you accomplished? How did you feel after?
content: Have you ever reached an important goal, something you had to work toward for a long time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: The ‘Unbearable’ Death of a Celebrity Hairstylist Leads to Flood of Tributes
description: Multiple former clients posted about their relationships with Jesus Guerrero, who died at 34. His family said Kylie Jenner volunteered to pay his funeral expenses.
content: Jesus Guerrero was not necessarily a household name, but he was a hairstylist to the stars, working with people like Jennifer Lopez, Kylie Jenner and Rosalía. So when his family announced on Sunday that he had died at 34, the tributes from his famous clients immediately began to flood social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Refused to Guarantee Ukraine’s Safety in Mineral Deal
description: Also, Timothée Chalamet is waging an unusual awards campaign. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: President Trump began his first cabinet meeting of his second term this morning by announcing that Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian leader, would visit Washington later this week to finalize a deal to give the U.S. a share of his country’s mineral revenues. However, Trump insisted that he would not provide security guarantees in return — rebuffing Zelensky’s central demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Given the Right Conditions, Could a Woman Run a 4-Minute Mile?
description: Researchers say it’s possible, at least for Faith Kipyegon of Kenya, who holds the world record for the distance.
content: Nearly three-quarters of a century after Roger Bannister of Britain, in 1954, became the first man to run a mile in under four minutes, an achievement that many at the time thought unattainable, scientists are saying they believe a woman could now also break the barrier and further expand the limits of human possibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Justice Dept. Nominees Suggest Some Court Orders Can Be Ignored
description: At a confirmation hearing, the nominees, two of whom have been Trump defense lawyers, offered little to assuage Democrats’ fears.
content: Lawyers for President Trump in line to take top jobs at the Justice Department sparred with Democrats on Wednesday over whether the administration could simply ignore some court orders — an early skirmish in a larger fight over the White House’s efforts to claim more sweeping presidential powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Trump’s Washington, a Moscow-Like Chill Takes Hold
description: A new administration’s efforts to pressure the news media, punish political opponents and tame the nation’s tycoons evoke the early days of President Vladimir V. Putin’s reign in Russia.
content: She asked too many questions that the president didn’t like. She reported too much about criticism of his administration. And so, before long, Yelena Tregubova was pushed out of the Kremlin press pool that covered President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Fortini
title: Why Are We So Obsessed With Blue?
description: The color has an unshakable hold on musicians, artists and writers.
content: “SUPPOSE I WERE to begin by saying that I had fallen in love with a color,” reads the first line of Maggie Nelson’s “Bluets,” her 2009 book-length lyric essay about the color blue. “Bluets” — the title refers to the delicate, diminutive wildflower but also to the abstract artist Joan Mitchell’s magnificent 1973 painting “Les Bluets” — is an elliptical exploration of heartache, the bluest of blue experiences, in the guise of a scholarly, metaphysical and emotional enchantment with one particular hue. “Each blue object could be a kind of burning bush, a secret code meant for a single agent,” Nelson writes of her affinity for the color, which she began to see everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Trump and Putin Are Coming Together. The World Is Coming Apart.
description: Even before the new Trump administration began to erode U.S. influence on autocratic countries, a diverse array of experts started to rethink the future of global democracy.
content: Soon after the Kremlin annexed Crimea in 2014, the former Polish president Aleksander Kwasniewski gave a speech in the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv to warn about the enduring nature of Russia’s imperial ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Head-Turning Fashion? Right This Way.
description: Outfits on and off the runways at London Fashion Week offered loads of inspiration.
content: Leading up to London Fashion Week, the vibes, as the saying goes, were off. More than a few brands scrapped shows they had been planning and others forewent planning them at all. But any doom and gloom as fashion week approached did not deter the most passionate fans, whose eclectic attire in and outside shows nodded to London’s sartorial tradition of bucking convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Thursday Briefing: An Israel-Hamas Hostage Exchange
description: Plus, the female gaze behind the camera.
content: What may be the last hostage exchange of this phase of the cease-fire was set to go forward late last night. Israel and Hamas have agreed to exchange the remains of four Israelis for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, Israel said, and mediators guaranteed that Hamas would hand over the coffins without “humiliating ceremonies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Early Humans Thrived in Rainforests
description: The discovery clashes with the traditional image of humans evolving on the savannas of East Africa.
content: For generations, scientists looked to the East African savanna as the birthplace of our species. But recently some researchers have put forward a different history: Homo sapiens evolved across the entire continent over the past several hundred thousand years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Another Sudden Departure Hits the Fashion World
description: Luke and Lucie Meier have left Jil Sander, joining an ever-growing list of designer departures.
content: At around 11 a.m. on Wednesday in Milan, Luke and Lucie Meier, the husband-and-wife duo who have been the Jil Sander creative directors since 2017, took a bow after their latest runway show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Mother-in-Law Wants to Be in the Delivery Room With Me. Help!
description: A reader asks for help setting boundaries with her husband’s mother, who has floated the idea of a lengthy stay with the couple after the arrival of their firstborn.
content: My husband and I are expecting our first child this year, and our parents will become first-time grandparents. As much as I love my mother-in-law, she can be controlling — even from 500 miles away. Recently, she told us that she wants to visit us monthly until the baby arrives and to stay with us for two weeks after the baby is born. Later, I heard that she told my husband and others that she wants to be in the delivery room! I know that this is all coming from a good place, but it feels overwhelming. I would prefer less frequent visits. My husband and I work full time, and our weekends are packed with baby planning. After the baby is born, we want time alone to bond as a new family. How can I politely set boundaries with my mother-in-law?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in Oregon, Massachusetts and New York
description: An Arts and Crafts house in Portland, a converted church in Yarmouth Port and a rustic compound in Tivoli.
content: This six-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bathroom house is in Willamette Heights, a few blocks from Forest Park, its picnic areas and trails. William C. Knighton, who designed the home, was also responsible for the Oregon Supreme Court building in Salem and the Sentinel Hotel in downtown Portland. A stretch of NW 23rd Avenue, five minutes away by car, is lined with shopping and dining options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Wildfire Burning on Table Mountain Moves Toward Cape Town
description: Firefighters have battled a blaze on the slopes in the national park for days. The fire spread overnight toward Cape Town’s central business district.
content: Firefighters in Cape Town on Wednesday were battling a wildfire that broke out in Table Mountain National Park and spread overnight toward the city, local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: At Funeral for Shiri Bibas and Children, an Israeli Outpouring of Grief
description: Thousands of Israelis lined the streets to mourn the Bibases, who were taken hostage in the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, 2023, and had become a symbol of the country’s trauma.
content: The people of Israel embraced them on their final journey, turning out in multitudes along the funeral route for a family that had become emblematic of the country’s trauma after the Oct. 7, 2023, attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Utah Could Become the First State to Ban Fluoride in Public Water
description: A bill before the governor would prohibit adding fluoride to water systems. The move could affect children’s health, experts warned.
content: Utah could soon become the first U.S. state to ban the addition of fluoride to drinking water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Writing the History of the Biden Presidency, in the Trump Era
description: A group of academics met to hash out a first scholarly history of the Biden administration. But in today’s scrambled politics, has the yardstick for success and failure changed?
content: Joe Biden left office with abysmal approval ratings — and faith that history would redeem him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Timothée Chalamet Does Awards Season a Little Differently
description: The 29-year-old actor has hit the usual stops, but the defining moments of his awards campaign have been distinctly online.
content: Going viral during awards season is not necessarily a good thing. Look no further than the unearthed social media posts of “Emilia Pérez” star Karla Sofía Gascón for the most extreme example of how an actor’s online behavior can sink a film’s chances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Natalie Proulx
title: Which Popular Phrases Annoy You?
description: “It’s all good.” “You’re perfect.” Are there any expressions people use today that you can’t stand?
content: “It’s all good.” “You’re perfect.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Who Makes the Red Carpet? Steve.
description: Steve Olive, who has worked in the event carpet business for more than three decades, is the man the Academy trusts to get its iconic rug just right.
content: On a recent weekday morning in La Mirada, a suburb outside Los Angeles, Steve Olive, 58, walked among hundreds of carpet rolls in red, green and lavender in a white, sun-drenched, 36,000-square-foot warehouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Authorities Say Thief Faked a Seizure to Steal Bulldogs From a Pet Store
description: Surveillance video at Perfect Pets in the Denver area showed a man opening dog kennels and running off with two bulldog puppies as another man appeared to create a diversion.
content: Around 1:30 p.m. on Friday, a man fell to the ground and went limp in a Perfect Pets outside Denver. He appeared to be experiencing a seizure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Garrison
title: On Seeing Timothée Chalamet as Bob Dylan at the AMC Clifton Commons
description: A poem from Deborah Garrison about watching the actor’s transporting performance in “A Complete Unknown” and what may be lost in translation between the generations.
content: This is why I hate movies.No, I hate going to the movies.Because I came out with a streaky tearface blinking into the dingy realityof the sticky patterned carpet and carrying the coldnear-empty popcorn box with kernels and stalepieces rattling — came from his almost comicanti-chivalrous beauty and from the burnished depthsof his living in another being, so much that aftera thought or two about the useful Jewish nose,made bold by the tall hair and unseen makeup(I can say this, I have a Jewish nose),I forgot he was Timothée.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdalrahman Altayeb and Lynsey Chutel
title: Military Plane Crash in Residential Area Kills at Least 46 in Sudan
description: The incident, whose cause was unknown, has added to the destruction wrought by years of civil war.
content: The crash of a military aircraft in a residential area of Sudan’s capital killed at least 46 people, regional officials said on Wednesday, adding to the devastation of a city already wrecked by nearly three years of civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Ridiculously Fun Clothes
description: With Doechii, Naomi Campbell and a lot of low-rise jeans, Dsquared2 celebrated its 30th year with a runway show fit for “Zoolander.”
content: I lost track of the number of cars. I lost track of the number of sparkly fringed leather chaps. I lost track of the number of butts hanging out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Covid Alarmists Were Closer to the Truth Than Anyone Else
description: Five years since a novel virus spread everywhere, it’s hard to remember what the beginning was like.
content: It’s been five years, and more than 20 million deaths globally. The first official case was in December 2019. The World Health Organization designated Covid-19 a public health emergency at the end of January 2020, the U.S. government declared it a national emergency on March 13, and every single state ordered or recommended schools close at some point between March 16 and March 27. What followed was trauma: years of mass mortality, inescapable infection and deep disruption, even to the lives of the relatively safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Michelle Trachtenberg Made the Mean Girl Sparkle on ‘Gossip Girl’
description: The actress embodied an arch flair that made the fabulous antagonist Georgina Sparks a fan favorite.
content: Georgina Sparks was not Gossip Girl, but she might as well have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: This Quick Vegetarian Ragù Is a Shortcut to Glory
description: An homage to a secret Tuscan recipe, this porcini-based sauce doesn’t need hours on the stove.
content: Only around 100 people live in Acone, a village high on a mountain in Tuscany first settled in the sixth century and mentioned in passing in Dante’s “Divine Comedy,” as the poet wanders through heaven. Ixta Belfrage thinks of that mountain as home, though she spent just a few years there as a child. She, too, wandered heaven, down rolling hills and roads lined with cypress trees as tall and slender as spires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: Theater Company’s Lost French New Wave Film Gets Its New York Premiere
description: Future members of Mabou Mines produced the footage over 50 years ago. Now it’s a film with new dialogue spoken by children of the original cast.
content: The French film industry was hardly the only force spurring the barricades, Molotov cocktails and worker strikes that were synonymous with Paris in May 1968. But the French government’s attempt to fire the head of the Cinémathèque Française earlier that year supplied crucial kindling. And while the Cannes Film Festival managed to open amid the unrest, with a glittery restoration of “Gone With the Wind,” Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut were among those who helped scuttle the festival at the halfway point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Drake Postpones 4 Australia and New Zealand Tour Dates
description: Dates for Brisbane, Sydney and Auckland were postponed for a “scheduling conflict,” representatives for the rapper said. The tour coincided with the release of his latest album.
content: Drake, whose new album topped the Billboard 200 chart this week after Kendrick Lamar had made him a punchline at the Super Bowl halftime show, has canceled four tour dates in Australia and New Zealand because of a “scheduling conflict,” representatives for the rapper said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Nebraska Man Struggles to Change Daughter’s Name From ‘Unakite Thirteen Hotel’
description: The name, which appeared to be generated by a computer, was meant to be temporary after the mother surrendered the child. But two years later, the nonsensical name remains.
content: When Jason Kilburn searched for his toddler daughter’s birth certificate, he was shocked to find that because of an error, she was legally named “Unakite Thirteen Hotel.” To make matters worse, she had no Social Security number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Rejecting Trump’s Call to Annex Their Nation, Canadians Rally Around the Flag
description: While Canadians are not generally known for flag waving, President Trump’s threats have led to a surge in flag sales and buffed up the national symbol’s image.
content: On a good day in February, Debbie Hartlen might sell one Canadian flag at her workshop in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia. Now, daily sales have hit roughly 300 flags, and that’s not counting her larger online business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon Unveils Alexa+, Powered by Generative A.I.
description: Amazon is aiming to catch up in generative artificial intelligence and to reboot its virtual assistant, which has been leapfrogged by powerful chatbots.
content: Amazon’s Alexa is undergoing its biggest overhaul since debuting more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Trump Administration Ends Global Health Research Program
description: The Demographic and Health Surveys were the only sources of reliable information in many countries on metrics such as mortality, nutrition and education.
content: An obscure but influential program that gave detailed public health information to about half of the world’s nations will fold as a result of the Trump administration’s freeze on foreign aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Mass Federal Firings May Imperil Crops, Cattle and Pets
description: The terminations, which hit agencies involved in protecting the nation’s food supply and agricultural products, could have long-lasting consequences, experts said.
content: Shortly after taking office for the second time, President Trump began making deep cuts to agencies and programs that play critical roles in human health, slashing funding for medical research, halting global health aid and firing scores of workers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Bezos Orders Washington Post Opinion Section to Embrace ‘Personal Liberties and Free Markets’
description: David Shipley, The Post’s opinion editor, is resigning after trying to persuade Jeff Bezos to reconsider the new direction.
content: Jeff Bezos, the owner of The Washington Post, announced a major shift to the newspaper’s opinion section on Wednesday, saying it would now advocate “personal liberties and free markets” and not publish opposing viewpoints on those topics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan McCarron
title: Why Is Egg Shopping So Unpredictable?
description: Some stores have none, others plenty, at all kinds of prices. Chalk it up to the complexities of how a once-ubiquitous staple arrives on shelves.
content: On Saturday morning in Culver City, Calif., Marie Hernandes finally found her eggs. A friend had asked for a vanilla birthday cake, so all week after work, she’d visited multiple stores — Ralphs, Target, Walmart — only to find the eggs sold out. Finally, an early-morning run to Costco landed her two 24-packs at $7.69 each.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Constant Méheut
title: Draft of Minerals Deal Features Vague Reference to Ukrainian Security
description: A copy of the agreement obtained by The New York Times says that the United States “supports Ukraine’s effort to obtain security guarantees needed to establish lasting peace.”
content: A draft of an agreement calling for Ukraine to hand over to the United States revenue from natural resources includes new language referring to security guarantees, a provision Kyiv had pressed for vigorously in negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: She Lobbied for a Carcinogen. Now She’s at the E.P.A., Approving New Chemicals.
description: Lynn Dekleva, who recently took a senior role at the agency, once led an aggressive effort by industry to block regulations on formaldehyde.
content: Formaldehyde, the chemical of choice for undertakers and embalmers, is also used in products like furniture and clothes. But it can also cause cancer and severe respiratory problems. So, in 2021, the Environmental Protection Agency began a new effort to regulate it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohana Ravindranath
title: Extreme Heat Linked to Accelerated Aging in Older Adults, Study Finds
description: A first-of-its-kind analysis found that people living in hotter areas experienced more molecular changes than those in cooler places.
content: Extreme heat can be particularly dangerous for older people, putting them at increased risk for heat stroke and death. But could it also affect how their DNA functions, and accelerate the aging process itself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: C.D.C. Suggests Terms Like ‘Race’ and ‘Health Equity’ Are Off-Limits, Then Backtracks
description: President Trump’s attacks on diversity, equity and inclusion efforts are making life difficult for some public health officials, who view eliminating racial disparities as part of their mission.
content: President Trump’s assault on diversity, equity and inclusion efforts is provoking heated debate within his administration — and the public health field more broadly — over whether words like “race,” “equity” and “disparity” are too politically toxic to use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Starmer Flies to Meet Trump, With a Gift and a Difficult Message
description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain cut international aid to raise military spending. He’s hoping to make a case for Ukraine at the White House.
content: Now it’s Keir Starmer’s turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca F. Elliott
title: Trump to Tighten Rules on Venezuela Oil Production
description: President Trump appears to be revoking a license that the Biden administration gave Chevron in 2022, potentially hurting the company and Venezuela.
content: President Trump said on Wednesday that he would revoke a Biden-era policy that allowed more oil to be produced in Venezuela and exported, dealing a blow to the country’s government and Chevron, which produces oil there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Paramount Pulls Back on D.E.I. Policies
description: The company has a merger with Skydance pending before the Federal Communications Commission, whose chief has criticized diversity, equity and inclusion hiring programs.
content: Paramount, the parent company of BET, MTV and the Paramount film studio, said on Wednesday that it was rethinking its approach to diversity, equity and inclusion amid a broader backlash toward D.E.I. policies driven by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily LaBarge
title: Steve McQueen and the Meaning of Resistance
description: A photography exhibition curated by the artist and filmmaker gathers nearly 200 black-and-white photographs showing a century of political struggles.
content: Collective action, marches, road closures and street clashes. Signs emblazoned, “No arms for Apartheid,” “Smash racism,” “Stop the Nazis,” “Freedom for Palestine,” “Equal pay now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer and Ephrat Livni
title: Israel and Hamas Exchange Prisoners and Hostage Remains
description: The militant group turned over four coffins it said contained the bodies of Israeli captives, and Israel began releasing Palestinian prisoners.
content: Hamas turned over what it said were the remains of four Israeli hostages early on Thursday, according to the Israeli military, and Israel began releasing Palestinian prisoners, in the latest such exchange during the initial stage of a fragile cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Will the ‘Tush Push’ Be Banned in the N.F.L.?
description: The league has received a complaint about the Eagles’ special play, in which the quarterback is pushed from behind. It may go the way of head slaps and forward fumbles.
content: Leaping over the line of scrimmage to block a kick. Standing in the end zone to swat away a field goal. Openly slapping an opponent in the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Barnard

title: Frankétienne, Father of Haitian Letters, Is Dead at 88
description: A prolific novelist, poet, painter and soothsayer, he was inspired by the chaos of his country and published the first novel written entirely in Haitian Creole.
content: The Haitian artist and writer known as Frankétienne, who published the first novel written entirely in Haitian Creole and who, as the nation’s foremost literary lion, refracted its chaos and disorder through art, died on Thursday at his home in Port-au-Prince, the nation’s capital. He was 88.

description: Girls prevailing against the odds is one theme that has surfaced among the 13 features and 79 short films in this year’s festival in New York.
content: A teenager rescues and defends an infant creature whose species the surrounding adults have condemned as vicious and predatory. Another adolescent battles injury and other hurdles in a quest for basketball stardom. A small child in Mexico contracts polio but finds solace in the world of art. And an 11-year-old Kurdish immigrant arrives in Berlin, ultimately relying on soccer talent to feel at home again.

title: ‘Fantasy’ AI Video, Shared by Trump, of Gaza as Luxury Resort Draws Scorn

content: President Trump on Tuesday night shared an AI-generated video depicting the devastated Gaza Strip as an opulent resort emblazoned with his name, less than a week after he appeared to back off his proposal to displace Palestinians en masse from the territory and assert U.S. control over it.

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Tango Passion as Muscular Feats
description: “Tango After Dark” at the Joyce Theater feels like an extended nightclub floor show, low in imagination and musical subtlety.
content: The dancers in “Tango After Dark,” an Argentine production that opened a two-week run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, are skilled, seasoned professionals. Their biographies list the many competitions they have won and the many shows in which they have performed, most with “tango” in the title. What distinguishes “Tango After Dark” from these other tango shows? Not much.

title: As Poverty Rises in New York City, 1 in 4 Can’t Afford Essentials
description: The share of New Yorkers in poverty is nearly double the national average, according to a report from Columbia University and an anti-poverty group.
content: A quarter of New York City residents don’t have enough money for staples like housing and food, and many say they cannot afford to go to the doctor, according to a report that underscores the urgency of an affordability crisis elected officials are struggling to confront.

content: On Tuesday, the Republican-led House approved a budget blueprint calling for significant cuts in federal spending, part of a plan to extend tax reductions enacted in 2017. The resolution does not say which programs should be cut, but Medicaid, which provides health coverage for roughly one in five Americans, most of them poor, will very likely come under scrutiny.

title: Along the Gulf, Residents Wonder: What’s in a Name?
description: President Trump’s order changing the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America prompted communities along the coast to think about the basin in a way many never had before.
content: In southernmost Louisiana, where the land on the map looks like grains of rice and okra in a bowl of gumbo, the body of water alongside it has always played a potent role. It has carried in ancestors, allowed for the industries that became the region’s backbone, delivered devastating storms and eroded the coast, lately at an aggressive clip.

content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, who rose from relative obscurity to become the Democratic nominee for vice president last year, will not run for his state’s open Senate seat in 2026 and will instead begin the process to seek a third term as governor, his spokesman said Wednesday.

content: Galina Timchenko, publisher and chief executive of the investigative newsroom Meduza, thought she was ready for anything. title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Wrong Parent Died’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Mom told me I was her rainbow baby long before she knew I was queer. I was the child after miscarriage, a rainbow, the antithesis of grief. When I confessed my queerness with a racing heart, she was quiet, forehead pinched. I wondered if she was again grieving the loss of a child, the child she thought I was. Then, on my 20th birthday, she sent a package of snacks. She called me later. “Did you get them? They’re rainbow Goldfish, just for you, my rainbow baby.” My friends still don’t understand why I cried over that bag of crackers. — Hannah Mark
